repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
rather than relying on __Pyx_pretend_to_initialize which isn't sufficient to avoid undefined behaviour there.

Fixes #5278

comment_data.body: I'm trying to think of situations where this simple replacement text might not be safe. What about function pointers, for example? Couldn't those have spaces after user defined type names, like a typedef name `sometypestruct` ending in `â€¦struct ` with a space?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2267,6 +2273,17 @@ def assure_gil(code_path, code=code):
                     code.putln("%s = %s;" % (Naming.retval_cname, err_val))
             elif not return_type.is_void:
                 code.putln("__Pyx_pretend_to_initialize(&%s);" % Naming.retval_cname)
+                # For C, __Pyx_pretend_to_initialize() is sufficient (taking an address
+                # is enough to make returning a variable defined). For C++ this isn't
+                # true, and we genuinely have to make sure a variable is initialized.
+                empty_decl_code = return_type.empty_declaration_code()
+                # C++ doesn't want names of the form '= struct foo()' so
+                # remove the struct
+                empty_decl_code = empty_decl_code.replace("struct ", "").replace("union ", "")

comment_data.body:
I think a function pointer would end to using `NULL` to signal an error so wouldn't get used by the "uninitialised return on error" path.

However, I take the general point here - I'll have another look. Worst case would be to restrict the replacement to the start of strings...

I think I've also missed `enum ` although they might also have a well-defined error return value.

(I think this change can miss the next beta though)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2267,6 +2273,17 @@ def assure_gil(code_path, code=code):
                     code.putln("%s = %s;" % (Naming.retval_cname, err_val))
             elif not return_type.is_void:

+                # For C, __Pyx_pretend_to_initialize() is sufficient (taking an address
+                # is enough to make returning a variable defined). For C++ this isn't
+                # true, and we genuinely have to make sure a variable is initialized.
+                empty_decl_code = return_type.empty_declaration_code()
+                # C++ doesn't want names of the form '= struct foo()' so
+                # remove the struct
+                empty_decl_code = empty_decl_code.replace("struct ", "").replace("union ", "")

comment_data.body: I've done this in PyrexTypes instead, which is a bit more verbose but should be more reliable

             elif not return_type.is_void:

+                # C++ doesn't want names of the form '= struct foo()' so

commit.message:
Initialize variables on C++

rather than relying on __Pyx_pretend_to_initialize which isn't
sufficient to avoid undefined behaviour there.

Fixes #5278
Remove "struct" etc from names more elegantly

title: Initialize return variables on C++
